channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russia Targets Power, Water and Heat for Ukraine’s Civilians
item.description: The stepped-up attacks on cities, including through the heavy use of Iranian-made exploding drones, threaten a new sort of humanitarian crisis for Ukrainians this winter.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers on Monday combed though the rubble of a building in Kyiv, Ukraine, that was hit by an exploding drone.

item.title: Iran Sends Drone Trainers to Crimea to Aid Russian Military
item.description: The trainers from Iran’s paramilitary wing have been deployed to help Russia overcome mechanical problems with the fleet.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protest outside the Iranian Embassy in Kyiv on Monday.

item.title: McCarthy Suggests a GOP-Led House Would Question Ukraine Aid
item.description: In an interview, the House minority leader, who is in line to be speaker should Republicans win a majority, said his party would resist giving a “blank check” to the war-torn country.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mr. McCarthy’s comments reflected the rising tide of isolationism in the Republican Party, especially in the House.

item.title: The Fed, Staring Down Two Big Choices, Charts an Aggressive Path
item.description: Federal Reserve officials are barreling toward another three-quarter-point increase in November, and they may decide to do more next year.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Federal Reserve is poised to raise interest rates three-quarters of a point next month.

item.title: IRS Announces Inflation Adjustments for Tax Rates in 2023
item.description: Filers whose salaries have not kept pace with inflation could see savings on their federal income tax bills.
item.dc:creator: Jim Tankersley
item.media:credit: Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.media:description: With inflation taking a bite out of paychecks, the Internal Revenue Service will increase the amount of income subject to taxes.

item.title: U.S. to Release Millions More Barrels of Oil to Contain Gas Prices
item.description: The Department of Energy will release 15 million more barrels from the Strategic Petroleum Reserve and plans additional releases this winter.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gas prices in the United States have risen again after easing in the summer.

item.title: Russian Analyst for Trump Dossier Acquitted of Lying to the FBI
item.description: John H. Durham, the special counsel who had been looking into the origins of the Russia investigation, failed to secure any convictions in three years.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Linda Qiu
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images
item.media:description: Two F.B.I. agents have testified that Igor Danchenko, who became a paid confidential source, had provided the bureau with valuable information.

item.title: Poll Shows Voters See Democracy in Peril, but Saving It Isn’t a Priority
item.description: A New York Times/Siena College poll found that other problems have seized voters’ focus — even as many do not trust this year’s election results and are open to anti-democratic candidates.
item.dc:creator: Nick Corasaniti, Michael C. Bender, Ruth Igielnik and Kristen Bayrakdarian

item.title: ‘You Don’t Look Anorexic’
item.description: New research shows that our assumptions about eating disorders are often wrong — and that many larger-bodied people are starving themselves.
item.dc:creator: Kate Siber
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sharon Maxwell is recovering from atypical anorexia. She suffered from disordered eating for 19 years before receiving a diagnosis.

item.title: Suspect in Stockton Serial Killings Charged With 3 Counts of Murder
item.description: A suspect was charged Tuesday in a series of murders in the California city, which has faced municipal bankruptcy, crippling crime waves and decades of setbacks.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka, Shawn Hubler and Holly Secon
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: A memorial for Jonathan Hernandez Rodriguez, who was murdered in August in Stockton, Calif.

item.title: Special Master Asks Trump Team to Back Up Privilege Claim
item.description: “What’s the expression — ‘Where’s the beef?’ I need some beef,” Judge Raymond Dearie, the independent arbiter, said during a conference call.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Rebecca Noble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Judge Raymond J. Dearie complained that an initial log of documents over which former President Donald J. Trump is seeking to claim privilege lacked sufficient information.

item.title: Trump Acknowledged in Interview That Letters to Kim Were ‘Top Secret’
item.description: Recordings made by Bob Woodward of his interviews with Donald Trump appear to contradict Mr. Trump’s claims that none of the documents he took with him from the White House were classified.
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Susan Walsh/Associated Press
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump and Kim Jong-un met in the border village of Panmunjom in the Demilitarized Zone in 2019.

item.title: For Broadway’s ‘1776’ Revival, the Drama Is Offstage
item.description: A cast member criticized the consciously progressive revival for its handling of race in rehearsals, saying there had been “harm done.” She later apologized for her comments.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson and Jennifer Schuessler
item.media:credit: Sara Krulwich/The New York Times
item.media:description: Sara Porkalob, center, as the South Carolina delegate Edward Rutledge in the musical “1776.”

item.title: How Atlanta History Shaped Lil Baby and Generations of Rappers
item.description: The city is home to one of the world’s most important musical ecosystems, and the 27-year-old is one of its biggest new stars.
item.dc:creator: Joe Coscarelli
item.media:credit: Kevin Amato for The New York Times
item.media:description: “It’s the upbringing, it’s the culture, it’s the things we see, the people we watched on TV,” Lil Baby said of Atlanta, his hometown. “It’s a repeating cycle of greatness.”

item.title: The U.S. Thinks ‘It Can’t Happen Here.’ It Already Has.
item.description: We don’t need foreign models to understand America’s authoritarian tendencies.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Capitol on Jan. 6, 2022.

item.title: Liz Truss in the Libertarian Wilderness
item.description: The political economy of a debacle.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; photograph by Jeff J Mitchell via Getty Images

item.title: The Fall of Liz Cheney and the Rise of Marjorie Taylor Greene
item.description: The Jan. 6 hearings were the final hurrah for Decent Republicans.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
Weapons of Mass Delusion: When the Republican Party Lost Its Mind (Book)
item.media:credit: Mark Peterson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marjorie Taylor Greene, ascendant in the Republican Party.

item.title: Thank You, Xi Jinping
item.description: China’s paramount leader is restoring faith in the free world — inadvertently, of course.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Mark R Cristino/EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Britain’s Liz Truss Is Finished
item.description: Britain’s prime minister may limp on, powerless, but she will fall.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Gold
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Daniel Leal, via Getty Images

item.title: A Utah Jury Acquitted Two Animal Rights Activists.
item.description: The acquittal of animal rights activists in Utah suggests attitudes may be changing about factory farming.
item.dc:creator: Wayne Hsiung

item.title: Reindeer Dog vs. the Swedish Tax Agency
item.description: Indigenous Sami tradition versus Swedish bureaucracy — who wins this dogfight?
item.dc:creator: Maria Fredriksson

item.title: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times

item.title: Can China’s leader deliver?
item.description: A party congress appears set to give Xi Jinping five more years in power. He has big goals for cutting greenhouse gas emissions, and big challenges.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:credit: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping this week at the 20th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party.

item.title: When the Music Stopped
item.description: Two stories about the power of music and the search for a deeper connection between a parent and child.
item.media:credit: Brian Rea

item.title: Affordable Oysters and More Reader Requests
item.description: Looking for the best happy hour deals with quality food? We have recommendations.
item.dc:creator: Nikita Richardson
item.media:credit: Lanna Apisukh for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Shukette in Chelsea, the Middle Eastern menu’s selection of oven-fired breads, richly spiced vegetables and seafood, and dips lends itself handsomely to group dining.

item.title: Jury Convicts Paul Flores of Murdering Kristin Smart in 1996
item.description: The California student went missing after Mr. Flores, a fellow student, escorted her to the dorms after an off-campus party. She was never seen again.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Daniel Dreifuss
item.media:description: Paul Flores during his trial in Monterey County Superior Court in Salinas, Calif., in July.

item.title: New York to Open Tent Camp for Migrants on Randalls Island
item.description: The facility, with about 500 beds for single men as well as a recreation center and cafeteria, is set to open Wednesday after buses arrive at Port Authority.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Randalls Island Humanitarian Emergency Response Center is an 84,400-square-foot facility that holds 500 beds for single men and also contains a recreation center and cafeteria.

item.title: Former Oath Keeper Says Militia Planned to Use ‘Any Means Necessary’ on Jan. 6
item.description: Testifying at the seditious conspiracy trial of the far-right group’s leader and four other defendants, an ex-member said the organization envisioned a battle breaking out in Washington that day.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Zach Montague
item.media:credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta/Associated Press
item.media:description: Members of the Oath Keepers standing on the East Front of the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021. The group’s leader and four other members are on trial for seditious conspiracy.

item.title: Not Just a Big Fish, but Perhaps the Biggest Bony Fish Ever
item.description: A sunfish found near the Azores in the Atlantic Ocean weighed as much as an S.U.V. Scientists say it’s a sign that the sea’s largest creatures can live if we let them.
item.dc:creator: Annie Roth

item.title: 5 Ways to Prevent Running Injuries This Marathon Season
item.description: Shin splints. Achilles tendinitis. Runner’s knee. Injuries abound for runners, but a sports medicine doctor offers ways to prevent them.
item.dc:creator: Dr. Jordan Metzl

item.title: Balance Exercises to Improve Your Strength
item.description: This simple, often neglected skill can pay huge dividends later in life.
item.dc:creator: Hilary Achauer
item.media:credit: Sarah Karlan for The New York Times

item.title: The Joy Workout
item.description: Six research-backed moves to improve your mood
item.dc:creator: Kelly McGonigal
item.media:credit: na

item.title: A Full-Body Strength Training Workout at Home
item.description: If you’re willing to be creative, a set of elastic bands can be as effective as a gym full of weights.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Marder
item.media:credit: Cayce Clifford for The New York Times
item.media:description: In addition to resistance training, exercise bands can take the edge off of body weight exercises, like pull-ups. But trainers like Vanessa Liu warn against becoming too dependent on them.

item.title: ‘Christian Girl Autumn’ Goes Back to Basic
item.description: Caitlin Covington became a meme in 2019 for her love of fall. Three years later, she’s leaning into it harder than ever.
item.dc:creator: Madison Malone Kircher
item.media:credit: Kelly Burgess for The New York Times

item.title: How to Solve Hard Crosswords
item.description: Friday, Saturday and Sunday bring some of the hardest puzzles of the week.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
